conclusion: To determine the amount of heat exchanged between the gas and the external environment during the cyclic process ABCDA, we need to analyze each segment of the cycle and apply the first law of thermodynamics, which states that the change in internal energy (ΔU) is equal to the heat added to the system (Q) minus the work done by the system (W): ΔU = Q - W
For a cyclic process, the change in internal energy over one complete cycle is zero (ΔU = 0), so the heat exchanged (Q) is equal to the work done (W): Q = W
Segment AB is an isothermal expansion.
The work done by the gas during isothermal expansion is W_{AB} = nRT ln(V2/V1).
The heat added to the system is equal to the work done: Q_{AB} = W_{AB} = nRT ln(V2/V1).
Segment BC is an isobaric expansion.
The work done by the gas during isobaric expansion is W_{BC} = P2 (V2 - V1).
The heat added to the system during isobaric expansion is Q_{BC} = nC_p ΔT.

premise: Using the ideal gas law, ΔT = P2 (V2 - V1) / nR.

conclusion: Segment CD is an isothermal compression.
The work done on the gas during isothermal compression is W_{CD} = -nRT ln(V2/V1).
The heat released by the system is equal to the work done on the gas: Q_{CD} = W_{CD} = -nRT ln(V2/V1).
Segment DA is an isobaric compression.
The work done on the gas during isobaric compression is W_{DA} = -P1 (V2 - V1).
The heat released by the system during isobaric compression is Q_{DA} = -nC_p ΔT.
